title: Sippysoft Service Desk Priority Levels
description:
General overview


Sippy Software Inc. provides support via the ticketing system which is based on the queue logic (first in first out) considering the priority of an incoming request.
Thus requests with the critical priority Sippy Support Department consider/investigate first by overcoming the standard queue logic. Such an approach may guarantee for every Sippy customer the fast resolution of some critical issues and fast recovery of any degraded service.


Task Priority Response time, hoursMain Criteria
Priority 1 (critical)HourlyThe customer's environment/system doesn't process calls (e.g. services totally down and customer can't run business)
Priority 2 (high) Every two hourscritical services do not work as expected (e.g web part is not responding or calls are degraded)
Priority 3 (medium)1 business dayservices are working fine but customer has some issue with system functionality (e.g. a customer-facing issues with making calls due to a misconfiguration of scenario on the web interface)
Priority 4 (low)2 business daysquestions and assistance in the configuration of some features and call scenarios


Response time commitments do not promise a complete resolution within the stated time frames. Rather, the time commitment is meant to indicate the maximum time interval in which the customer will be contacted by either the technician assigned to the ticket, or by the assigned department’s manager to initiate support activities. Every effort will be made to immediately respond to and resolve all critical issues.


Priority Definitions


Priority 1 (critical): an issue impacting the whole system. When an issue with Priority 1 occurs on the customer's end, it is important that Sippy Support Department has a clear understanding of the severity of the issue, so that the necessary resources can be applied to resolve the issue.


Examples: (but not limited by the following list):

    

  • The web interface is fully down.
  • A critical network issue due to which the whole service is down.
  • The customer's environment/system doesn't process calls.
  • The server is down (HW issue, critical Software issue). 


Priority might be changed/decreased when service is restored/renewed.


Priority 2 (high): some component/service is degraded but the major part of services are still operational and the major part of a traffic flow isn't affected. Priority could escalate to Critical if not addressed quickly.


Examples: (but not limited by the following list):

    

  • The web interface is degraded but operational;
  • The network is degraded but the core services are up and running.
  • Calls are degraded due to the issue with some component/service (e.g. media proxy is degraded).


Priority might be decreased (if service restored/renewed) or increased (if the service stopped responding totally).


Priority 3 (medium): Routine requests that impact a single user or non-critical software or hardware issue. Operation of core services isn't affected. 


Examples: (but not limited by the following list)::

    

  • Misconfiguration in call scenario which leads to a call failure.
  • Single user unable to use some component/service but for other users, the same service works fine.
  • Software/Hardware installations, upgrade, etc.

Priority might be decreased or increased depending on the provided resolution by Sippy Support Department.


Priority 4 (low): A minor service issue or some general question or assistance in configuration.

Examples (but not limited by the following list):

    

  • Assistance in configuration review.
  • Feature requests.
  • Explanation of some technical material.

Priority might be decreased or increased depending on the provided resolution by Sippy Support Department.
